oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Towards an Understanding of Black Girls’ Digital Activism: What the Black Girls’ Literacy Framework Reveals About the Digital Literacy Practices of Adolescent Black Girls
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Odlum, Lakisha
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American girls
critical media literacy
black girl literacies
social justice
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This qualitative study explored the digital literacy practices of adolescent Black girls who actively engaged on social media in the aftermath of the murders of Breonna Taylor and George Floyd. I employ intersectionality and the Black Girls’ Literacies (BGL) framework (Haddix & Muhammad, 2016) to analyze six qualitative interviews I conducted with adolescent Black girls who avidly used video sharing social media during that time. The data analysis aligned with the following components of the BGL Framework: Black girls’ literacies are intellectual, political, and critical. Moreover, the data analysis also revealed that Black girls espoused two different identities while using social media to address anti-Black violence. These themes were: Crafting Digital Narratives of the Self as Educators and Crafting Digital Narratives of the Self as Digital Activists. The study concludes with national, district-wide, and schoolwide recommendations for policy to improve the teaching and learning of adolescent Black girls.
